content.description:
Aeneas on the Shores of the Styx

Quisquis es, armatusarmatus, -a, -um, adj.: armed qui nostra ad flumina tendis, 
fare age, quid venias, iam istincistinc, adv.: from there et comprimecomprimo, -ere: to restrain comprimo, -ere: to restraingressumgressus, -us, m.: step. 
Umbrarum hic locus est, somni noctisque soporaesoporus, -a, -um, adj.: sleep-bringing: 
corpora viva nefasnefas, n.: an impious act StygiaStygius, -a, -um, adj.: Stygian, of the river Styx vectarevecto, -are: to carry carinacarina, -ae, f. = navis, -is.
content.question: In line 2, what is the mood of comprime?

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 1.B: Describe how grammar contributes to the meaning and function of Latin words and phrases in context.
